properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Southerly winds will reach up to 90 km/h overnight tonight and Friday. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-25T20:57:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-25T04:57:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2074268472.2020
Area: Grande-Vallée area, Sainte-Anne-des-Monts area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rainfall totaling 30 to 50 mm is expected to continue this evening and into Friday. The frozen ground will have a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Hazards: 30 to 50 mm of rainfall Timing: Rain will continue this evening and last through Friday morning. Discussion: Rain is forecast to continue intensifying this evening, with periods of heavy rain likely tonight. Rain will ease to showers and then snow flurries Friday. A total of 30 to 50 mm of rain is expected across eastern Ontario. For information concerning flooding, please consult your local Conservation Authority or Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry District office. Visit Ontario.ca/floods for the latest details. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-25T19:00:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-25T03:00:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3115654728.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A snowfall of 10 to 20 cm is expected tonight. Hazards: 10 to 20 cm of snow Quickly accumulating snow at times Timing: This evening through Friday mid-morning Impacts: Poor road conditions due to black ice and snow accumulation Discussion: The snow may become heavy at times this evening and overnight, with snowfall rates of 2 to 3 cm per hour possible at times. Snow should gradually ease into scattered flurries Friday morning. Some uncertainty remains regarding total snowfall amounts, however, for much of the Niagara Region and areas just west, it appears 15 cm is likely enough to warrant a snowfall warning. Note: Environment Canada's criteria for Snowfall Warnings is 15 cm of snow in 12 hours or less. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-25T14:21:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-24T22:21:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0433320384.2020
Area: Dunnville - Caledonia - Haldimand, City of Hamilton, St. Catharines - Grimsby - Northern Niagara Region, Niagara Falls - Welland - Southern Niagara Region
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rain and windy conditions are expected. Total rainfall: 30 to 50 mm. Locally 60 mm possible. Maximum wind gusts: 60 to 80 km/h with higher wind gusts possible along the Fundy Coast and over higher terrain. Time span: Showers will develop today then become heavy rain this evening. Remarks: Rain is expected to switch to periods of snow Saturday afternoon before ending on Saturday evening. In addition, strong gusty winds will develop today and they will reach close to the warning criteria (90 km/h) along the Fundy Coast. These strong winds will diminish by Saturday morning. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-26T00:41:44-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Warm, wet and windy conditions for Friday and Saturday followed by periods of snow late on Saturday. Total rainfall: 25 to 50 mm. Locally 60 mm possible. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm and locally possibly exceeding 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 70 to 90 km/h with the highest gusts along the Fundy coast and over higher terrain, beginning on Friday and diminishing on Saturday. Locations: all of New Brunswick. Time span: Light rain will begin on Friday, and intensify on Friday night and Saturday morning, before moving east of the province late on Saturday. Rain is expected to switch to snow for most areas on Saturday afternoon or evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-25T18:29:45-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Warm, wet and windy conditions for Friday and Saturday followed by periods of snow on Saturday evening. Total rainfall: 25 to 50 mm. Locally 60 mm possible. Total snowfall: locally 5 to 10 cm or possibly more especially over higher terrain. Maximum wind gusts: 70 to 90 km/h with the highest gusts over exposed areas. Location: western Nova Scotia and Cumberland County. Time span: Light rain will begin on Friday, intensify on Saturday, and move east of the province Saturday evening or overnight. Remarks: A low pressure system approaching from the Great Lakes will bring rain to the province beginning on Friday and intensifying overnight into Saturday. Rain is likely to switch to snow for some areas on Saturday evening as the system pulls away. Winds will strengthen ahead of this system, nearing warning levels for much of the province. Conditions will improve Saturday night. In addition, higher than normal water levels are expected from Lunenburg east to Sheet Harbour near 4 am AST on Saturday. Wave heights of up to 6 metres are expected along the Atlantic coast beginning early Saturday and persisting most of the day. Significant coastal flooding is not expected at this time. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-25T18:28:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-25T02:28:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2827130420.2020
Area: Kings County, Annapolis County, Digby County, Lunenburg County, Queens County, Shelburne County, Yarmouth County, Cumberland County - Minas Shore, Cumberland County North and Cobequid Pass

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected Friday and Saturday. Hazards: 15 to 30 cm of snow in the heaviest bands Quickly accumulating snow at times Poor visibility in blowing snow and heavy snow Timing: Friday midday through Saturday Impacts: Hazardous driving conditions due to poor visibility and accumulating snow Discussion: Lake enhancement may help enhance widespread snowfall Friday morning before more intense pure lake effect snow develops in the afternoon. These snow squalls will last into Saturday. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Several hours of freezing rain is expected tonight, particularly over higher terrain. Places along the Ottawa River, such as Pembroke and Petawawa, are not expected to be impacted by freezing rain as much as higher terrain areas to the southwest. Hazards: Several hours of freezing rain, particularly over higher terrain Ice accretion of up to 5 mm Timing: Freezing rain will develop late this evening and continue into Friday morning Impacts: Local power outages may be possible due to ice build-up Generally, impacts should be mainly confined to areas of higher terrain, but places along the Ottawa River may still get into a couple hours of freezing rain by Friday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Utility outages may occur. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-25T16:59:33-00:00

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: southeasterly up to 100 km/h in the Wreckhouse area. Time span: Saturday morning until Saturday overnight. Remarks: Strong southerly winds will develop this morning gusting to 80 km/h. Winds will strengthen on Saturday out of the southeast gusting to 100 km/h. Winds will ease upon shifting to westerly overnight on Saturday. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected on Friday and possibly Saturday. Hazards: 15 to 30 cm of snow in the heaviest bands Quickly accumulating snow at times Poor visibility in blowing snow and heavy falling snow Timing: Friday morning into Saturday Impacts: Hazardous driving conditions due to reduced visibilities and snow accumulation Discussion: Cold northwesterly winds flowing over the warmer waters of Lake Huron will generate snow squalls beginning Friday morning. Steady winds and sufficient temperatures will allow for blowing snow in areas with fresh snowfall. A general 5 to 10 cm can be expected with up to 30 cm in areas where bands settle for longer. Poor visibility will be a concern throughout the watch area. These snow squalls could potentially last into Saturday. Conditions should improve Saturday evening. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-25T17:11:40-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow continues with snow squalls developing by this morning. Hazards: 5 to 15 cm of snow Heavy snowfall at times Timing: Widespread snow will continue into this morning. Impacts: Hazardous road conditions Discussion: Snow continues across the region. In particular, a band of heavy snow has developed along the eastern Lake Huron shoreline and south across Middlesex County and western Elgin County. This band should gradually weaken and shift northeastwards with time. Snow Squalls should start developing off Lake Huron in the coming hours...and Snow Squall Warnings will likely be needed. Please refer to the Snow Squall Watch in effect for these details. A widespread 5 to 15 cm is expected by morning from widespread snowfall. Reports of 5 to 8 cm of snow have been received so far. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-25T17:59:36-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow tonight before snow squalls Friday. Hazards: 5 to 15 cm of snow by Friday morning Potentially dangerous road conditions Timing: Widespread snow will transition to more localized/variable lake effect snow squalls Friday morning. Discussion: Snow is underway across much of southwestern Ontario, Snow will continue tonight and may be occasionally heavy at times overnight into Friday morning, with a general 5 to 10 cm of snow expected, though locally some areas may approach 15 cm. Lake effect snow squalls will develop Friday morning, and continue into Saturday. The Snow Squall Watch in effect will take care of this threat. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-25T18:58:14-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected today. Hazards: Locally 15 to 30 cm of snow Quickly accumulating snow of 5+ cm per hour Blowing snow Poor visibility in heavy and blowing snow Timing: 4 a.m. to 1 p.m. Impacts: Hazardous to dangerous travel Locations impacted possibly include: London, Grand Bend, Parkhill, Strathroy, Lambton Shores, The Pinery Provincial Park, Melbourne, Mount Brydges, Komoka, Komoka Provincial Park and Ilderton. Discussion: Exeter weather RADAR shows a snow band forming over Lake Huron at present. Short term guidance has this band getting more organized and coming inland near Grand Bend and reaching between London and Strathroy. Intense snowfall rates may be possible for several hours this morning before the band shifts north this afternoon. Blowing snow may accompany this snow squall as well. Travel could be dangerous. Note: heavy snow from the main low pressure system will continue in these areas as well over the next few hours. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-25T19:59:24-00:00

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall, combined with melting snow, is expected. Snow, rain and record high temperatures are on the way. Total rainfall: 20 to 35 mm with higher localized amounts possible, especially over higher terrain. Locations: western and central Labrador. Time span: Friday morning until Friday overnight for the heaviest rain but showers or periods of rain may continue until Sunday. Remarks: Snow will change to rain, at times heavy, early on Friday. The rain is expected to taper off overnight Friday night. Record high temperatures are forecast for Friday, Saturday, and possibly even into Sunday. The rain combined with these extreme high temperatures will lead to significant snowmelt and increased runoff leading to a greater chance for flooding. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-25T18:54:28-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Strong winds expected Christmas Eve. A deepening area of low pressure currently over Explorer will track off Haida Gwaii tonight. The low will spread southeast 90 km/h winds to Haida Gwaii and exposed coastal sections of North Vancouver Island this evening. The strong winds will ease overnight and shift to southwesterly as the low marches on towards the Gulf of Alaska ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory continues. 10 to 15 cm of snowfall is expected by this morning. Hazards: 10 to 15 cm of snowfall Periods of heavy snow Timing: Snow will continue through this morning Impacts: Poor winter road conditions due to black ice and accumulating snow Discussion: Widespread snowfall continues tonight across south central Ontario. Heavier snow may move in over the next few hours, with snowfall rates of 2 to 3 cm per hour possible during this time. Road conditions will continue to be hazardous tonight. Snowfall intensity should begin easing by 5 a.m. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A snowfall of 15 to 25 cm continues. Hazards: 15 to 25 cm of snow Quickly accumulating snow at times Timing: Continuing into this morning Impacts: Poor road conditions due to black ice and snow accumulation Discussion: Widespread snow continues tonight. Heavy snow with snowfall rates of 2 to 3 cm per hour remain possible at times over the next few hours. Snow should gradually ease into scattered flurries late this morning. As of 11 p.m., Hamilton Airport has reported 8 cm of snow. Weather spotter reports of 7 to 10 cm have been received from across the region so far as well. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected on Friday and possibly Saturday. Hazards: 15 to 30 cm of snow Quickly accumulating snow at times Reduced visibilities in blowing snow and heavy falling snow Timing: Friday morning into Saturday Impacts: Hazardous driving conditions due to reduced visibilities and snow accumulation Discussion: Cold northwesterly winds flowing over the warmer waters of Lake Huron will generate snow squalls beginning Friday morning. These snow squalls could potentially last into Saturday. Conditions should improve Saturday evening. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-25T13:37:20-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall possible on Christmas Day. A developing low pressure system, southeast of lake Erie, is forecast to track northward tonight. Snow ahead of this system will spread across the region tonight and gradually taper off Friday night. A total snowfall accumulation of 5 to 15 cm is possible with this event with the highest amounts expected closer to the Quebec border. Although the snow amounts do not meet Snowfall Warning criteria of 15 cm or greater in 12 hours or less, there may be brief periods of heavy snow on Friday that may make travel difficult over some locations. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-25T20:14:52-00:00
